item.title: U.N., Warning of Migrant Crisis in Greece, Urges Europe to Act
item.description: With the nation’s economy in crisis, the body’s refugee agency said the Continent had a responsibility to help deal with the surge.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Syrian migrants arriving on the Greek island of Lesbos last month. More than 77,100 people have reached Greece by sea since the start of the year, 60 percent of them from Syria, and roughly 1,000 more arrive each day.

item.title: Chinese Authorities Appear to Detain 4 Human Rights Lawyers
item.description: The reasons for the moves against the lawyers remained unclear, but several lawyers and activists suspected an effort to crush China’s “rights defense” movement.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Putin Criticizes U.S. Role in Afghanistan, Saying Security Hasn’t Improved
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia delivered the remarks at a gathering of regional leaders, including the Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, third right, with other regional leaders at the Shanghai Cooperation Organization summit in Ufa, Russia, on Friday.

item.title: Stampede in Bangladesh Kills at Least 23 at Clothing Handout
item.description: More than 2,000 people, most of them residents of slums, had assembled outside the home of a factory owner for the giveaway.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: The bodies of some of the stampede victims in the Bangladeshi district of Mymensingh on Friday. Officials said the death toll was expected to rise.

item.title: Stampede in Bangladesh Amid Clothes Handout Kills at Least 23
item.description: More than 2,000 people, most of them residents of slums, had assembled outside the home of a factory owner for the giveaway.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: The bodies of some of the stampede victims in the Bangladeshi district of Mymensingh on Friday. Officials said the death toll was expected to rise.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Britain’s Dangerous New Tribalism
item.description: The real threat to social cohesion is not enmity between Muslims and non-Muslims but a regressive politics of identity.
item.dc:creator: KENAN MALIK

item.title: Worries Wane Over Extreme Drought in North Korea
item.description: Rainfall in the North reached 90 percent of normal for June after an especially dry May, said Jeong Joon-hee, a spokesman for the Unification Ministry in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Rice fields in Nampho, North Korea, in June. Rainfall in North Korea that month had recovered to 90 percent of normal after an especially dry May.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Kenneth G. Lieberthal on the Political Effects of China’s Stock Market Plunge
item.description: Mr. Lieberthal, an observer of Chinese politics and a former policy maker in Washington, discusses the implications for President Xi Jinping, who until now had benefited from an aura of omnipotence.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Letter From Europe: Panel Questions Whether West Tapped U.N. Chief's Communications
item.description: Before the plane crash that killed Dag Hammarskjold in 1961, were intelligence agencies bugging the encryption device he used to communicate?
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Conservationists in China Seek to Get Firefly Parks Closed
item.description: In recent years, a number of commercial enterprises have tried to tap into the country’s growing nostalgia for the pulsating flickers. But environmental groups are racing to catch up.
item.dc:creator: SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Fireflies near Wuhan, Hubei Province. On Thursday, Shanghai's first firefly exhibit canceled its opening over safety issues.

item.title: India Inquiry Into Scandal Over Testing Set to Expand
item.description: The Supreme Court of India ordered the federal authorities to take over a probe into a testing scandal in the state of Madhya Pradesh that has involved numerous arrests and possibly deaths.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: What You Need to Know About China’s Draft Cybersecurity Law
item.description: China, which has some of the world’s tightest Internet restrictions, has released a draft of a bill that authorizes broad powers to control the flow of online information.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Surveillance cameras in Tiananmen Square, Beijing. The release of draft legislation on cybersecurity in China followed the recent passage of a law on national security.

item.title: Stock Market Plunge in China Dents Communist Party’s Stature
item.description: Investors have asked why the Communist Party and the government talked up the markets in recent months and then bumbled in efforts to prevent the rout.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Investors at a brokerage in Shanghai this week. Across China, many of the millions of middle-class investors have been asking why the government talked up the market in the months leading up to the recent hemorrhaging.

item.title: World Briefing: North Korea: Pesticide Factory May Have Sinister Purpose, Report Says
item.description: A pesticide factory recently visited by the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un may be used to produce biological weapons, like anthrax, according to an online report.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: Palestinian TV Channel Temporarily Banned
item.description: An Israeli cabinet minister signed an order barring a Palestinian television channel geared toward Israeli Arabs from operating inside Israel for the next six months.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Gen. Tahsin Sahinkaya, a Leader in Turkey’s 1980 Coup, Dies at 90
item.description: General Sahinkaya was the last surviving member of the junta whose power grab ended years of violence but also set off a wave of government-imposed repression and torture.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Saud al-Faisal of Saudi Arabia, Quiet Force in Middle East, Dies at 75
item.description: Prince Saud, who served for four decades as Saudi Arabia’s foreign minister, was known for his behind-the-scenes, conservative diplomacy in a time of major changes.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Prince Saud al-Faisal of Saudi Arabia in 2014. He helped to settle a civil war in Lebanon and to smooth bumps in a tight relationships with the U.S.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Can the U.S. and China Get Along?
item.description: Relations are at their worst point since 1989. To avoid conflict, bold steps are needed.
item.dc:creator: ORVILLE SCHELL

item.title: Surge of Ebola in Liberia May Be Linked to a Survivor
item.description: The conclusion was made by scientists who analyzed the genetic sequence of the virus from the body of a Liberian boy who died of Ebola last week.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK

item.title: In Bolivia, Pope Francis Apologizes for Church’s ‘Grave Sins’
item.description: Francis repeated familiar themes in sharply critiquing the global economic order and warning of environmental catastrophe — but also added a new twist with his apology.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and WILLIAM NEUMAN
